characters: LOADING OS... PERFORMING HARDWARE CHECK... INT TEMPERATUR
JUST AS THEY REACH EACH OTHER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE RED PLANET momentarily eclipses the Sun. As sunlight breaks across the edge, warming the surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're MOVING THROUGH the channels of Acidalia Planitia to find the ARES 3 HAB SITE.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: All right, team. Stay in sight of each other. Let's make NASA proud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ASTRONAUT MARK WATNEY. He's in the middle of an experiment. He chips at a section of rocks and records hi observations on his ARM COMPUTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright-eyed and optimistic. Another day at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In grid section fourteen twenty-eight, the particles appear predominantly "coarse," but as we move to twenty-nine, the particles are much finer, and should be ideal for chem analysis.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Hear that, everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we FIND RICK MARTINEZ inspecting the MARS ASCENT VEHI (a.k.a "The MAV") on the launch pad. They speak over radi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark just discovered "dirt." Alert the media.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your job today, Martinez? Confirming the MAV is still upright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visual inspection of equipment is imperative to mission success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez studies the MAV for a moment, then speaks thoughtfully into his arm computer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The MAV is still upright."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney, you keep leaving your channel open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIND COMMANDER MELISSA LEWIS across the way, overseeing a drill experiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which leads to Martinez responding, which leads to us listening, which leads to me being annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez, Commander Lewis would like you please shut your smart mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking for the smart people of the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. CHRIS BECK studies samples on slides at his station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would prefer you use a different adjective to describe Martinez' mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Beck just insult me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Beck. And yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to turn their radios off from here, Commander...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETH JOHANSSEN sits inside at her computer, tracking (amo other things) the group's communications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen, constant communication is the hallmark of a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut `em off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. Mark and Martinez' radios go SILENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lewis works, we see Mark throwing up his arms in the background, like "Hey! C'mon!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for my countrymen, Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX VOGEL wears the EUROPEAN UNION patch on his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accepted. How many samples do we need, Commander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven. One hundred grams each. Drill at least thirty centimeters down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the two of them use a SPECIMEN DRILL to bore holes the ground, we see Mark waving his arms in the background C'mon, turn my radio back on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen frowns as she receives a MISSION UPDATE from Houston. Her face goes PALE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Commander? You should come inside...

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: You're gonna want to see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis reads the tension in Johanssen's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a mission update. Storm warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the warning in the morning briefing. We'll be inside long before it hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've upgraded their estimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm's gonna be worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS looks to the skies. IN THE DISTANCE: a STORM darken the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle MARK: as the dirt in front of him starts to blow in incoming WIND...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis reads the update. Everyone else is inside as well. Mood is grim -- this is not good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...twelve-hundred kilometers in diameter, bearing 24.41 degrees..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's tracking right towards us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...based on current escalation, estimate a force of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Eighty-six hundred Newtons."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the Abort Force?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything above that and the MAV could tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're scrubbed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Begin abort procedures."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone tries to hide their crushing disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it won't be as bad as they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're estimating with a margin of error. We can wait it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's wait it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LEWIS. This news hits her worst of all. She tries to consider all her options. Mind RACING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prep for emergency departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're scrubbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HIGH WINDS slam into our five astronauts as they exit airlock. They struggle to stay on their feet as they figh their way through the punishing storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visibility is almost zero. If you get lost, home in on my suit's telemetry. The wind's gonna be rougher away from the Hab, so be ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sand continues to slam them as they take step after agoni step towards the MAV. It's brutal; they fight for every i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Maybe we could shore up the MAV. Make tipping less likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use cables from the solar farm as guy lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pauses to catch his breath. Starts forward again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rovers could be anchors. The trick would be getting around the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! A massive section of antenna SLAMS INTO MARK out of nowhere. He's lifted off his feet and YANKED away into th storm. It happens FAST. One second he's there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something hit him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney, report --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's offline. I don't know -- Commander, before we lost where he is -- telemetry, his decompression alarm went off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Johanssen where did -- He was right in front of you last see him? me and then he was gone. He flew off due west --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis surveys the scene. Visibility is NEAR ZERO. She can barely see the people next to her. Tries to keep her hear from POUNDING out of her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... okay... Martinez, get to the MAV and prep for launch. Everyone else, home in on Johanssen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Beck! How long can a person survive decompression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Line up and walk west. Small steps. He's probably prone. We don't want to step over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group fights through the chaos --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOSH! Martinez dives into the airlock, forces the door closed. Waits for agonizing seconds as it pressurizes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressurized. Martinez races up the ladder, slides into th pilot's couch and boots the system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander -- The MAV's got an 8 degree tilt. It'll tip at 12.3 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck checks the readout on his arm computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen, Watney's bio-monitor sent something before going offline. My computer just says "Bad Packet" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't finish transmitting. (works her arm computer) I have the raw packet. It's plaintext: BP 0, PR 0, TP 36.2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood pressure zero. Pulse rate zero. Temperature normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temperature normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a while for the... it takes a while for the body to cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stops short as that news lands.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Commander. Tilting at 10.5 degrees now, with gusts pushing it to 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy. If it tips, can you launch before it completely falls over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. Yes. Ma'am. I could take manual control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy that. Everyone home in on Martinez' suit. That'll get you to the airlock. Get in and prep for launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Commander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm searching a little more. Get moving. And Martinez, if you start to top, launch.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: You really think I'm leaving you behind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just ordered you to. You three, get to the ship. (as they hesitate) GO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogel, Beck, and Johanssen stumble into the airlock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis can't see a thing in any direction. C'mon, think, Melissa, think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches into the pack on her back and removes two of one meter drill bits she was using earlier to take sample She holds one in each hand, dragging them on the ground a she trudges through the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen, would the rover IR camera do any good?

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (INTO RADIO)
dialogues.text: Negative. IR can't get through sand any better than visible light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rip off their helmets. Scramble up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she thinking? She's a geologist. She knows IR can't get through a sandstorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's grasping. For anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander. We're tilting 11.6 degrees. One good gust and we're tipping.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: What about the proximity radar? Could it detect Watney's suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. It's made to see Hermes in orbit, not the metal in a single suit.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Copy. Give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck slides into his acceleration couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander, I know you don't want to hear this, but Watn... Mark's dead.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez, try the radar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Martinez waits for the radar, he glares at Beck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend just died. I don't want my Commander to die too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis fights her way through the storm.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Negative contact on proximity radar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can barely see the Hab. There's not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREEEACH -- the MAV lurches, begins to tip --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strap in! We're tipping!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 degrees -- -- We're past balance. We'll never rock back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it tip. We can't leave her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never be able to fix it if it tips. I got one trick left, then I'm following orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOSH -- Martinez fires a burn from the nosecone array. thrusters fight against the slow tilt of the spacecraft..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are firing the OMS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon... c'mon... 12.9 degrees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander. You need to get back to the ship. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed. He's gone, Ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis stands alone in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Watney's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares out at the darkness all around her. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez fights the controls. Beck and Johanssen share nervous glances. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Copy. On my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOSH. Down below, Lewis slams the airlock door shut. Sh tears off her suit. Makes her way to the flight cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't say a word as she straps herself in to her co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, nobody speaks. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still at pilot release. Ready for launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis closes her eyes. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Commander. You need to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez nods. Activates the sequence. The pyros FIRE. Th main engines IGNITE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON LEWIS. Just as the MAV LURCHES UPWARD, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEODORE "TEDDY" SANDERS, Director of NASA, steels himsel before he steps to the podium. Normally, he leaves these briefings to his press secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is different. He opens a RED FOLDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At around 4:30 a.m., central standard time, our satellites detected a storm approaching the Ares 3 mission site on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By 6:45, the storm had escalated to "severe," and we had no choice but to abort the mission. Thanks to the quick action of Commander Lewis, astronauts Beck, Johanssen, Martinez, and Vogel were all able to reach the Mars Ascent Vehicle and perform an emergency launch at 7:28 central time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, during the evacuation, Astronaut Mark Watney was struck by debris and killed. Commander Lewis and the rest of her team were able to intercept safely with the Hermes and are now heading home... (wavers, then) But Mark Watney is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CACOPHONY of questions erupts from the press --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear skies above the surface of Mars once again. PRELAP sound of an ALARM: ARRR... ARRR... ARRR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BODY lies facedown, half-covered in red sand at the bas a hill. We catch a glimpse of the nametag on the spacesui

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Watney."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OXYGEN ALARM inside the helmet continues to BLARE. An just as it builds to crescendo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark Watney gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks back into consciousness. He's disoriented, alarm BLARING inside his helmet. As he struggles to move...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams in pain. Glances down. Sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JAGGED LENGTH OF ANTENNA has pierced his spacesuit and stabbed straight into his abdomen. CAKED BLOOD all around the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's training kicks in -- the suit is breached -- he struggles to his knees -- gasping in pain -- he reaches t the side of his helmet for the BREACH KIT -- pulls the va free -- grabs hold of the antenna... grits his teeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND YANKS the antenna out of his side. The antenna SNAPS FREE -- the suit is exposed to atmosphere -- the pressure inside DROPS -- Mark CRIES OUT, goes woozy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But stays conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the breach kit over the hole. Seals it. Checks h arm readout. The oxygen stabilizes. He's still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles to his feet. Picks up the length of antenna. Begins the LONG CLIMB up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're WITH MARK as he makes the climb, and as he crests t hill we swing around to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ARES 3 HABITATION (a.k.a. "The Hab"): The large, whit tent-like structure where the six crew members lived duri their time on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been battered by the storm, but it's still intact. M registers momentary relief. But then his eyes dart over t the MAV LAUNCH SITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark fumbles his way into one of the hab's airlocks. As s as the airlock equalizes, he tears off his helmet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stumbles into the main area. Peels off his jumpsuit. WINCES as he rips the blood-caked fabric away from HIS WO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fingers probe the puncture. It's deep. That's bad. He checks his back for an exit wound. There's none. That's good. He grabs the broken antenna he brought with him. Hi fingers trace the bloodied end. It's jagged -- as though piece of the antenna broke off inside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stumbles over to the first-aid station. Grabs suppli Anesthetic. Syringe. Forceps. Needle. Suture thread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This is not exactly going to be easy to watch.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweat pouring off his brow, Mark loads up the syringe wit anesthetic. Grits his teeth. Injects it into his wound. Gasps. Breathes. Grabs the forceps. Hesitates. I don't want to do this. He takes a deep breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And digs the forceps into his wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He CRIES OUT in pain. Nearly goes unconscious. Fights it. Don't pass out, Mark. He probes with the forceps, grimaci in agony. He can't find it. Pushes the forceps in deeper. And DEEPER. Jesus. Mark's face goes WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds it. Yanks the forceps free. Sees the small piece of shrapnel. It's out. Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark grabs the needle. Tries to thread it. His hands won' stop shaking. He makes fists. C'mon Mark. Steadies himsel just enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to stitch himself up. Bit by agonizing bit. His hands keep shaking, but he refuses to stop until the woun closed. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's done. He clips the sutures. Collapses back into his chair. Oh Jesus. Tries to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly ANGLE IN ON MARK as he struggles to breathe... breathe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as we settle into a CLOSEUP, we see the full reality Mark's situation hit him. He's in agony. Left for dead. All by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only man on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes drift to the middle distance. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM ANGLE: we're looking through what (we assume) is a NA camera. Mark's head peeks into frame. He adjusts the camera, seems unfamiliar with how to work the video journ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He types on the keypad. We see the NASA TIMESTAMP appear the frame. There, it's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is... Mark Watney. Astronaut. I am entering this log for the record, in case I... don't make it. It's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oh-six-fifty-three on Sol 19. And... I'm still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously. But I'm guessing this is going to be a surprise to my crewmates. And NASA. And... the world. So... surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't die on Sol 18. Best I can tell -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds up the jagged piece of antenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this length of our primary communications antenna tore through my bio-monitor. And ripped a hole in me as well. It was horrible thank you for asking. But the antenna... and the blood... managed to seal the breach in my suit. Which kept me alive. Even though the team must have thought I was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Lewis... If you ever hear this... Listen. It wasn't your fault. Just bad luck. You did what you had to do, and if I had been in your position I would have done the same. I'm glad you guys made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, though. That's where we're at. Mark Watney, stranded on Mars. I have no way to contact NASA because our communications antenna broke and stuck into my stomach. Which we've covered. And even if I could, it will take... four years before the next manned mission gets here. And I'm in a Hab designed to last thirty-one days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the oxygenator breaks, I'll suffocate. If the water reclaimer breaks, I'll die of thirst. If the Hab breaches, I'll just sort of... implode. And if, by some miracle, none of that happens... eventually I'm going to run out of food. So... yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark trails off. It's one thing to know it. It's another say it out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits in his bunk. Drumming his fingers on the wall. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first slivers of sunlight start to creep over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark flushes the toilet, which begins the procedure of va drying the waste. Mark glances back at the system. Hmmm..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system finishes its process, sealing the waste into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark studies the bag. Idea forming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inventory. Mark removes all of the ration packs, stacking them in orderly piles as he catalogues their contents. On case in particular catches his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Label: "DO NOT OPEN UNTIL THANKSGIVING."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits in the darkness. We get the sense he hasn't mov much in the night. He stares into the middle distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes the decision. Get up, Mark. He gets to his feet. Moves with purpose as he rummages through the hab. Lookin for something. Where is it? There...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a notecard free from one of his manuals. Paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to basics. He sits at the table. And begins writing math equations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do the math...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark addresses camera. He looks a little less-terrible th he did before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our surface mission here was supposed to take thirty-one days. For redundancy, they sent enough food to last for sixty- eight days. For six people. So for just me, it'll last three-hundred days. And I figure I can stretch that to four hundred if I ration. So... I've still gotta figure out how to grow three years worth of food. Here. On a planet where nothing grows. Luckily, I'm the botanist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds up one of his mission briefs. Points to the wo "Botanist" under "Watney." Looks at us like, impressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mars will come to fear my botany powers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark collects the pile of silver bags. Carries them insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands in the kitchen, surrounded by silver bags. He fills a large container with water from the Reclaimer. He dumps in the contents of the compost bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he stares at the bags. He does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears open a bag. Dumps the contents into the bin. Tea open another bag. As he does so, he starts to GAG --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark scoops Martian dirt into a container with a small shovel. He carries the container to the airlock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark enters the Hab, dumps his container of dirt into a corner where he's cleared an empty area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same shot. Mark enters with another container. We follow reveal... there's now a HUGE PILE of dirt in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark has spread the dirt over a third of the Hab floor. H stares at the compost bin. Eyes it like it's his nemesis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he takes a deep breath. Opens the bin. Begins dumpin it over the Martian dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't hold his breath forever. He breathes eventually. Oh god, that's horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark cuts each potato into four quarters, making sure eac quarter has at least two eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins planting each potato quarter in nice, orderly r As he works, we slowly WIDEN OUT to reveal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENTIRE HAB is now covered in SOIL. Not just the floor Mark has cleared every available surface -- bunks, countertops, table -- and covered it with his dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark packs soil on top of one of the crew member's bunks. he moves the personal items aside, he finds a DATA-STICK. holds it up and looks at it: hmmmm. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark has plugged the data-stick into the computer and is viewing its contents: old episodes of seventies televisio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark just sits there. Watching HAPPY DAYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark trudges out to the Mars Descent Vehicle (MDV) -- the lander that brought the six of them to Mars. He delicatel begins to remove the Hydrazine tank from the undercarriag

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've created one-hundred and twenty-six square meters of soil. But each cubic meter needs forty liters of water to be farmable. So, I gotta make a lot of water. Fortunately, I know the recipe. Take hydrogen. Add oxygen. Burn. Unfortunately... burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have hundreds of liters of unused Hydrazine from the MDV. If I run the Hydrazine over an iridium catalyst, it'll separate into N2 and H2...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Science time. Quick cuts now as Mark shows us how to make water by burning rocket fuel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark duct tapes torn trash-bags to create a tent, whic uses to cover his work table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He tears an air hose from one of the space suits, tape to the tent, hangs it from the roof. Now he has a chimney

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark vents pure oxygen from a tank, lights it with a s from battery wires. Whoosh. Points the flame at the wood shavings. Now he has a small torch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark holds the torch, starts the Hydrazine flow. The Hydrazine sizzles on the iridium and DISAPPEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW Mark's gaze up to the chimney. FLAME BURSTS start sputtering out from the hose. Mark grins. It's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark checks his instruments. Watches the temperature carefully. Repeats the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may also notice Mark is wearing the protective inner lining of his EVA suit. Along with goggles. An oxygen mas hangs around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks directly to camera. We may notice he is standi in the middle of what looks like a mad-scientist's chemis experiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I just need to direct the hydrogen into a small area and burn it. Luckily, in the history of humanity, nothing bad has ever happened from lighting hydrogen on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark just stares at the camera. Then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, the challenge has been finding something that will hold a flame. NASA hates fire. Because of the whole "fire makes everyone die in space" thing. So everything we brought with us is flame retardant. With the notable exception of... Martinez' personal items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up Martinez' pack. Removes a small wooden cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Martinez. If you didn't want me to go through your stuff, you shouldn't have left me for dead on a desolate planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts shaving the cross down with a knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure God won't mind, considering the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's still at it. He looks exhausted. He goes through t procedure once again. Glances at the atmospheric analyzer Hm. Is that right? Doesn't give it a second thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes the torch again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explosion is LOUD, FAST, and CONTAINED. It blasts Mar clear across the room. He hits the ground like a wet rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks to camera. His clothes are somewhat scorched. His hair is singed in patches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Yes. I blew myself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best guess? I forgot to account for the excess oxygen I've been exhaling when I did my calculations. Because I'm stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still dazed. A little out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting side note: this is how Jet Propulsion Laboratory was founded. Five guys at Cal Tech were trying to make rocket fuel and nearly burned down their dorm. Rather than expel them, Professor... Von Karman? I want to say... banished them to a nearby farm in Pasadena and told them to keep working. And now we have a space program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? I pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get back to work. As soon as my ears stop ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just sits there for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's back at it. He checks his math, adjusts the O2 levels. He glances at camera, then crosses his fingers. Winces as he fires up the torch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't blow up. Phew. Starts venting the hydrazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Mark steps back from the table. Wipes the sweat fr his brow. Looks at his hands. Sweat. He walks over to the walls. Sees the condensation. Beads of water everywhere. He traces them with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as though he's created a rainforest in his Hab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the WATER RECLAIMER. Takes the lid off the TA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now FILLED with water. Mark grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: we see the entire Hab. The surfaces covered wi soil, the cramped living space, the mad-scientist experim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark works at the table. And as he does so... we begin to SPEED UP. Time lapse photography:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark vents the Hydrazine -- Mark checks his readouts -- M collects water from the reclaimer -- Mark spreads the wat over his soil -- Mark eats lunch -- Mark goes back to wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving faster and FASTER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sleeps -- Mark puts on his spacesuit -- Mark exits t Hab -- Mark brings in more dirt -- Mark vents Hydrazine - Mark eats -- Mark sleeps --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the days FLY BY, we're slowly ANGLING towards the b of the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark works Mark eats Mark sleeps Mark works --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towards a small patch of SOIL in the corner. We land in CLOSEUP: soil filling the frame. We HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single, green SPROUT breaks through the soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And FROM BLACK, we FIND EARTH. The calming blue-greens a welcome reprieve from the fiery reds of Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy speaks before a memorial. A somber crowd listens in silence. We watch from far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our nation was blessed to have Mark serving in our space program. His loss will be deeply felt, but the men and women of NASA will soldier forth, onward and upward, unbroken in the mission of their agency. In doing so, they honor the legacy Mark leaves behind, and they ensure his sacrifice will not be in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN walks past the NASA logo greeting visitors at the g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man enters the main lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards glance up from the television, nod hello. As Vince walks through security, we catch a glimpse of their scree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CNN TITLE reads: "President Speaks At Watney Memorial."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Vincent makes his way through NASA, we notice EVERYONE THE BUILDING is watching news reports of the Watney servi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREENS: We catch a brief glimpse of a female astronaut floating in zero-g, eulogizing Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sits at his desk, staring out the window. We recogn him from the beginning of the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TELEVISION, we see Teddy shake hands with the President at the service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent gives it a passing glance as he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you gave a lovely speech, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one for small talk, Teddy gestures for Vincent to han him the request form he's holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to authorize my satellite time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy gives it a quick glance, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're funded for five Ares missions. I think I can get Congress to authorize a sixth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They evac'd after eighteen sols. There's half a mission worth of supplies up there. I can sell another mission at a fraction of the cost. I just need to know what's left of our assets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the only one who needs satellite time. We've got the Ares 4 supply missions coming up. We should be focusing on the Schiaparelli Crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about securing us another mission. We have twelve satellites in orbit, we can surely spare a few hours --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about the satellite time, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent shrugs -- then what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a public domain organization. We have to be transparent about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second we point the satellites at the Hab... I broadcast pictures of Mark Watney's dead body to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of a PR problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm afraid of a PR problem. Another mission? Congress won't reimburse us for a paper clip if we put a dead astronaut on the cover of The Washington Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what do we do? He's not going to decompose. He'll be there forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meteorology estimates he'll be covered in sand from normal weather activity within a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't wait a year for this. We have work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ares 5 won't even launch for another five years. We have plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent thinks about it. Frustrated. Tries another tack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, consider this. Right now, the world is on our side. Sympathy for Watney's family is high...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows this sounds cold, but he's out of options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ares 6 could bring the body back. We don't say that's the purpose of the mission, but we make it clear that would be part of it. We frame it that way, we get more support in Congress. I can sell it. But not if we wait a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy stares back out the window. Vincent has a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a year, people won't care any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN in her twenties checks the work order on her scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She straightens up when she sees the request comes from "KAPOOR, Vincent." She enters the latitude and longitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acidalia Planitia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart starts to beat a little faster. Click. The imag pop up: overhead shots of the Hab site. Morbid curiosity getting the better of her, she scans for Mark's dead body Doesn't find it. Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She zooms in on the Hab. That's strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then it hits her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know what to do. It takes her a moment to fin the phone. Heart POUNDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security? This is Mindy Park in SatCon. I need the emergency contact number for Dr. Kapoor. Yes, him. Yes it's an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hard-charging WOMAN stares at us in SHOCK --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you have GOT to be SHITTING ME --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: ANNIE MONTROSE, Director of Media Relations, NASA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, Vincent, and Teddy all huddle in the conference ro IMAGES of the HAB site on the screens around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly 100%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand the shitstorm that's about to hit us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, one thing at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to images) For starters, the solar panels have been cleaned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could have been cleaned by wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Rover 2. According to the logs, Commander Lewis took it out on Sol 17. Plugged it into the Hab to recharge. It's been moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could have forgotten to log the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the clincher. Check the MDV. It's been taken apart. There's no way they do that without telling us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we talk to Lewis? Let's go to CAPCOM and ask her directly right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent shoots Teddy a glance. After a moment, Teddy understands what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. If Watney is really alive... we don't want the Ares 3 crew to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? How can you not tell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have another ten months on their trip home. Space travel is dangerous. We need them alert and undistracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They already think he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they'd be devastated to find out they abandoned him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on board with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to protect the crew. There's nothing they can do anyway. Let them deal with the emotional trauma when they're not trapped in a spaceship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we handle the public?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have twenty-four hours before we're required to release the pics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll need to release a statement with them. We don't want people working it out on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear America. Remember that astronaut we thought we killed and had a nice funeral for? Turns out he's alive and we left him on Mars. Our bad. Sincerely,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get on a plane to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Why? Oh...) Mark's parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should hear it from me before it breaks on the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be happy to hear their son's alive, at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's alive. But if my math is right, he's gonna starve to death long before we can help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly looking forward to that conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent's eyes drift to the images of Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you even imagine what he's going through? He's fifty million miles from home. He thinks he's totally alone and that we all gave up on him. What kind of effect does that have on a man's psychology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he thinking about right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna die up here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares directly into camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if I have to listen to any more goddamn disco music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now notice that Vicki Sue Robinson's "Turn the Beat Around" is playing on the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Commander Lewis, you couldn't have packed anything from this century?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not turning the beat around. I refuse to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at his work station, checking A MAP of Mars whi he makes calculations.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's time to start thinking long term. The next NASA mission is Ares 4. It's supposed to land at the Schiaparelli Crater, 3,200 km away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mark trace a route from his position to the crater

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: NASA presupplies each mission years in advance, so the MAV is already there, synthesizing fuel. In four years when the Hermes returns, I'll have to launch from there. Which means I gotta get to the crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts. Mark rips the (VERY large) battery out of Rov 1 and drags it over to Rover 2. Stares at it. Where am I gonna put this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark speaks directly to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But here's the rub. I've got two rovers designed to go a max distance of 35 kilometers before they need to be recharged at the Hab. That's problem A. Problem B is it'll take me... roughly fifty days to make the journey. So I have to be able to live for fifty days. Inside a rover with marginal life support the size of a small van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yeah, problem C is if I don't figure out how to make contact with NASA in the first place, none of this matters anyway. So... yes, in the face of overwhelming odds, I am left with only one option:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have to science the shit out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: The bouncing bass line of "Rubberband Man" by T Spinners carries us through --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark attaches the battery to Rover 2 with a makeshift harness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark sits behind the wheel of his wagon train. Takes i for a test drive. It's not pretty, but the spare battery HOLDS. As do the solar cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark speaks to the camera. His teeth are chattering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so... success? I've doubled my battery life by scavenging Rover 1. BUT. If I use the heater, it'll eat up half my battery power every day. If I don't use the heater, I will be slowly killed by the laws of thermodynamics. (tries to stop shaking) I'd like to solve this problem, but unfortunately my brain is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark drives back towards the Hab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark drives the Rover across Acidalia Planitia. IN THE DISTANCE: a GREEN FLAG is planted at the top of a hill.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good news: I may have a solution to my heating problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark climbs the hill.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bad news: it involves me digging up the Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now, if I remember my training correctly, one of the lessons was titled, "Don't Dig Up The Big Box of Plutonium, Mark..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark begins to dig up the big box of plutonium.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I get it. RTGs are good for spacecraft, but if they rupture around humans... no more humans. Which is why we buried it when we arrived. And planted that flag so we would never be stupid enough to accidentally go near it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark unearths the RTG. It looks like a small missile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But. As long as I don't break it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost said "everything will be fine" out loud. My point is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks to camera while he drives the rover. He's cove in sweat. He even has his shirt off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not cold anymore. And yes, I could choose to think about the fact that I'm warm because I have a decaying radioactive isotope riding shotgun next to me, but right now I have bigger problems on my hands. I've scoured every single data file on Commander Lewis' personal drive, and this is officially the LEAST disco song she owns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hits play on the computer. "Hot Stuff" by Donna Summ starts playing. It's super disco-y. Mark drives, stone- faced, while it plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rover heads towards the Hab in the distance, growing smaller and smaller in frame. Gotta have some HOT LOVE ba this evening... Hot hot hot hot... stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SATELLITE IMAGERY: from above, Mark's rover cuts across M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Watney going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CNN REPORTER conducts an interview with Vincent in the MEDIA ROOM. Annie watches like a nervous stage mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe he's preparing for a journey. He's conducting incremental tests -- taking Rover 2 out for longer and longer trips each time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what end? Why would he leave the relative safety of the Hab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Communication. We believe he plans to travel to the Ares 4 launch site in order to make contact with us. But it would be a dangerous gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd be risking his life to talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the problem Mark faces. He's alone. And he needs to make contact to survive. But if we could talk to him, we'd tell him to stay put. Mark needs to trust we're doing everything in our power to bring him home alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venkat walks quickly down the halls with Annie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say "Bring him home alive." It reminds the world he might die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think people might forget that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked how you did and I'm giving you my answer. My answer is "Eh." And yes, I'm going to make everyone forget there's a strong likelihood Mark Watney is going to die because that's what you pay me for and unfortunately I need this job because I'm currently paying alimony to two deadbeat ex-husbands because somehow gender equality has bitten me square in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to believe tha--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Annie enter just as the rest of the Departmen Heads are settling for the meeting. Teddy glances up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say "Bring him home alive," Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, these interviews aren't easy. God forbid I try to say something proactive and positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more Vincent on television. Copy that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent starts to muster an "are you kidding me?" as Mind passes out a brief to the department heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-six kilometers. Am I reading that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's quite sure who Teddy is asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Mark drove straight away from the Hab for almost two hours, did a short EVA, then drove for another two. We think the EVA was to change batteries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who seems to embody the word "gruff" stares at Mind over his brief. Who is this kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we doing a daddy/daughter thing today? Where's the Director of SatCon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: MITCH HENDERSON, Hermes Flight Director, NASA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Park is the person who figured out Mark was alive in the first place. She's in charge of tracking him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit being a dick, Mitch. Where's Mark going? Is this another test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's seventy-six kilometers away from the Hab. If it's a test and it doesn't work... he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't load up the Oxygenator or the Water Reclaimer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see that happen, no sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every forty-one hours, we have a seventeen minute gap. It's just the way the orbits work. So... it's possible we missed something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that gap down to four minutes. I'm giving you total authority over satellite trajectories and orbital adjustments. Make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (um...) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's assume Ms. Park didn't miss something, so Mark's not going to Ares 4. Yet. But he's smart enough to figure out that's his only chance. Bruce, what's the earliest we could get a presupply there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy looks to the brilliant-but-constantly-harried man skyping in on the computer screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: BRUCE NG, Director, Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the positions of Earth and Mars, it'll take nine months. And it'll take us six months to build it in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna say that's impossible, then I'm gonna give a speech about the blinding capabilities of the JPL team. And then you'll do the math in your head and say something like "The overtime alone will be a nightmare."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oh god I didn't even think

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The overtime will be a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get started. I'll find you the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to tell the crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, we discussed this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You discussed this. But I'm the one who decides what's best for the crew. They deserve to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mitch. I'm with Vincent. They need to concentrate on getting home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once we have a real rescue plan, we'll tell them. Otherwise it's moot. Bruce has three months to get the payload done. That's all that matters right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark dies if you don't. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hab has been TRANSFORMED into a makeshift GREENHOUSE. Plants sprout everywhere. Mark uproots some of the potato cuts them in pieces. Replants them.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's been 48 sols since I planted the potatoes, so now its time to reap and re- sow. They grew even better than I expected. I now have 400 healthy potato plants. The smaller ones I'll re-seed. The larger ones are my food supply. All natural, organic, Martian-grown potatoes. You don't hear that every day, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, by the way, none of this matters, at all, if I don't figure out how to make contact with NASA...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to work. Mark sits at the table, studies his maps. H can't crack the problem. C'mon, Mark, think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it hits him. He zooms in on the map. We catch a glimpse of two words: "Chryse Planitia." Mark leaps from chair. Studies the map up close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. Whispers to himself. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SATELLITE VIEW: Mark's Rover 2 cuts through Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the move again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent huddles over Mindy's screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is he going? He hasn't changed course in thirteen days. And he's nowhere near course for Ares 4...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless he's not taking a direct route. Maybe he's trying to avoid some obstacle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What obstacle? It's Acidalia Planitia. There's nothing out there but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent stops short. Mindy looks at him: what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent bolts away. Mindy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent hurries into the employee break room. A lone TECHNICIAN sits, sipping coffee. ON THE BACK WALL: a larg poster of Mars (the type they sell in gift shops.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent rips the poster off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- c'mon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll buy you a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the Hab's location?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31.2 degrees north, 28.5 degrees west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent marks it off on the map with a sharpie. Draws Mar location. He needs a ruler. Looks around, grabs the Technician's notebook out of his hands. Uses the spine to connect the dots. Studies it. Grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where he's going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent, lost in his own world now, bolts for his office. he hurries away (leaving Mindy and the Technician behind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get on an airplane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honestly not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's Rover 2 crests a hill, approaching HIS DESTINATION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, buried in a mound of Martian sand, we catch a glin metal in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark drives towards it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce waits in the lobby as Vincent walks through the fro doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, California

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Vincent hurry across the JPL campus. In the background, deer frolic. (NOTE: This is real. Deer frolic out in the open on the JPL grounds. NOTE: It's awesome.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the odds Mark can get it working again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say. We lost contact in `97. We think it was battery failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I'd like to point out it lasted three times longer than expected in any scenario.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's criticizing JPL's work, Bruce. I want talk to everyone who was here in `97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're already waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, on foot now, digs at the location. As he begins to reveal the buried metal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce enter the cavernous JPL garage. A large crowd mills around an APPARATUS covered by a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This the replica?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce nods, pulls off the sheet to reveal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathfinder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American spacecraft launched in 1996. It's in two notable sections -- the large LANDER and the smaller SOJOURNER ROVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent's eyes gleam as he stares at the craft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark has now uncovered Pathfinder. He stares at it with a similar gleam in his eye. Then he drags the Lander to the back of Rover 2, begins lashing it to a makeshift hitch..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sojourner now sits beside the workbench outside the Hab, watching as Mark methodically takes apart the Lander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like he's been at this a while. He removes the battery, replaces it with an environment heater. Like a surgeon performing a heart transplant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He locks the heater into place, and as it CLICKS we --

dialogues.speaker: 34C, EXT TEMPERATURE
dialogues.text: Okay, LOGAIN: Okay, METEOROLOGY: NONFUNCTIONAL, SOLAR A:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent, Bruce, and the JPL team see the words come up on main screen. The room begins to BUZZ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at the high gain antenna on the Lander. It starts to MOVE... angling towards Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark begins to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce cluster around the station of TIM GRIME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as I received the high-gain response, I directed Pathfinder to take a panoramic image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you received it yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I thought we would all rather look at this black screen instead of a vibrant red planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Vincent's look) Tim is our finest comm tech, and we all appreciate his acerbic wit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce mouths "I will fire you" to Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREENS: the panoramic starts to appear, one verti stripe at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martian surface... more surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the Hab!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The image reveals a handwritten note, posted on a metal r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll write messages here. Are you receiving?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The image reveals two more notes, spaced a few feet apart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Point here for yes." "Point here for no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-two minute round trip communications time. He can only ask yes/no questions, and all we can do is point the camera. This won't exactly be an Algonquin round table of snappy repartee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger that. Pointing the camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark watches as the camera moves towards one of his notes We ANGLE IN on the paper, focusing on one word in particu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here's the rub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark addresses camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow, we need to have complex astrophysical engineering conversations using only a still-frame camera. From 1996. Luckily, the camera spins 360, so I can make an alphabet. I just can't use our alphabet. Twenty-six letters plus question card into 360 gives us 13 degrees of arc. Too narrow. I wouldn't know what the camera was pointing at. So. Hexadecimals to the rescue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark methodically sets up cards marked "A-F" and "0-9" in circle around the camera.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I figured one of you guys kept an ASCII table somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits in Johanssen's bunk. Scrolling through her lapt

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you supernerd Beth Johanssen, who also had copies of Zork 2 and Leather Goddesses of Phobos on her laptop. Seriously, Johanssen... it's like the Smithsonian of loneliness on there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim consults an ASCII chart as he points the camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera swings from card to card...

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not that I'm complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark translates the numbers with his ASCII table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark ponders the question. Begins writing his response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Impaled by antenna. Bio-monitor destroyed. Crew had reas to think me dead. Not their fault."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark inputs the code into the rover's computer.

dialogues.speaker: WATNEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now that we can have more complicated conversations, the smart people at NASA have sent me instructions on how to hack the rover so that it can talk to Pathfinder. If I hack a tiny bit of code, just twenty instructions in the Rover's operating system, NASA can link the rover to Pathfinder's broadcasting frequency... and we're in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark waits patiently at the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Text pops up on Mark's screen. As he reads:

dialogues.speaker: VENKAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Mark, this is Vincent Kapoor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce huddle around Tim's console while Vince dictates and Tim types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been watching you since Sol 54...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy, Mitch, Annie, and the rest of the team watch Vince text cross the screen.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "The whole world is rooting for you. Amazing job, getting Pathfinder. We're working on rescue plans. Meantime..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark reads the text. His first human contact in quite som time.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "We're putting together a supply mission to keep you fed until Ares 4 arrives."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce huddle around Tim's console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Glad to hear it. Really looking forward to not dying."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs, cheers. Tim notices there's more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "How's the crew? What did they say when they found out I was alive?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce share a glance. Vincent thinks about it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him. Hm. Tell him... 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark watches the text pop up onscreen:

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "We haven't told the crew you're alive yet. We need them to concentrate on the mission."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole room waits patiently. Tim reads the response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says... "They don't know I'm alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What the... f-word... f-word in gerund form... f-word again... is wrong with you... f-words."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, please watch your language...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark reads the response.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything you type is being broadcast live all over the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's eyes narrow as he types his response. Hits ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group reads Mark's response. They go PALE. Oh, Jesus. Vincent hangs his head. Tim tries not to smile and fails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy is on the phone as Mitch approaches.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes sir... he's under a tremendous amount of stress... I understand. We're working on it. Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy hangs up. Glances at Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had to explain to the President of the United States what a "bureaucratic felcher" is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made the mistake of typing it into Google. (off Teddy's look) Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem is, Mark's right. This is only gonna get worse the longer we wait. We need to tell the crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bringing this up while Vincent's in Pasadena so he can't argue the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have to clear this with you or Vincent or anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time, Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE HERMES: the massive spacecraft makes its way through space on its long journey back to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: Four Months Since Mars Departure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ANGLE towards one of the windows to FIND COMMANDER LEW staring out at the starfield...

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Commander Lewis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis is alone, in a secluded section of the ship. She ke the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (OVER RADIO)
dialogues.text: Data dump is almost complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy. Coming to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis floats towards the Semicone-A ladder. MARTINEZ beat her there. As he floats up the ladder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son turned three yesterday. Should be some pics of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they make their way down the ladder, the centripetal f from the rotating craft creates artificial gravity. Halfw down, they have to use their hands on the ladder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis and Martinez enter the Rec Room. The others are already there -- the data dump is the highlight of the da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, we've got a batch of personals. Dispatching them to your laptops... I don't need to read Vogel's weird German fetish emails...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are telemetry updates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever does it for you. We've got a system update, I'll take care of that, and... huh. There's a voice message. Addressed to the whole crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen opens the message. Hits play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hermes, this is Mitch Henderson. I have some news. There's no subtle way to put this: Mark Watney is still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news hits the crew like a freight train.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (MESSAGE)
dialogues.text: I know that's a surprise. And I know you'll have a lot of questions. Here are the basics: he's alive and healthy. We found out two months ago and decided not to tell you. I was strongly against that decision. We're telling you now because we finally have communication with him and a viable rescue plan.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (MESSAGE)
dialogues.text: We'll get you a full write up of what happened, but it's not your fault. Mark stresses that every time it comes up. Take some time to absorb this. Your science schedules are cleared for tomorrow. Send all the questions you want and we'll answer them. Henderson out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment the group sits in stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He... He's alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogel cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck starts to laugh. Relief pouring out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Commander! He's alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Lewis is still in shock. Her words barely a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left him behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander... it wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all left together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were following orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left him behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group trades glances, but nobody knows what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without another word, Lewis turns and exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark removes water from the water reclaimer. Goes down th rows of plants, watering one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that NASA can talk to me, they won't shut up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got a room full of people trying to micromanage my crops. Which is awesome. Look, I don't mean to sound arrogant here, but I'm the best botanist on the planet. So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark adjusts the camera to show more of the lab. We see t lush greenery of the potato plants EVERYWHERE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other news, there's been a request for me to pose for a picture on the next transmission. I'm debating between "High School Senior..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark leans one elbow against an imaginary pillar and hook his other thumb on his imaginary belt loops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And "Coquettish Ingenue..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark turns his back to camera, looks at us over his shoul and bites on his thumb suggestively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not sure how that will translate with the spacesuit on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One big bonus of this NASA communication: Email! Just like the days on the Hermes, I get data dumps. Not just friends and family, but NASA also sends choice messages from the public. Rock stars, athletes, even The President. The coolest one is from my alma mater, the University of Chicago. They say once you grow crops somewhere, you have officially "colonized" it. So, technically, I colonized Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your face, Neil Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: "Right Back Where We Started From" by Maxine Nightingale takes us into... 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mark stands outside in his suit. Positions himself in front of the camera. Holds up a notecard. We're behind hi we don't see what the notecard says. As he poses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie tosses a photo on the conference room table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, in his spacesuit, gives the camera a big thumbs-up. holds up a note that says, "Ayyyyyyy!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask for a picture and I get the goddamn Fonz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Bruce are both on monitors from JPL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be grateful you got something, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna work. I need something with less-Happy-Days and more... Mark's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could tell him to take his helmet off, but then he'd, you know, die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's release the photo when we detail the rescue operation. I want to announce we're launching some supplies to him next year during the Hohmann Transfer window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on a plane to you this afternoon. We'll have the release ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
