dialogues.text: Good, but Annie will handle camera appearances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent gives a look that says "Et tu, Teddy?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, is your team still on schedule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be tight. But we'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine-month travel time, that puts the probe to Mars on Sol 868. Did we get the Botany Team's analysis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They estimate Mark's crops will last him until Sol 912. They grudgingly admit Mark is doing great work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grudgingly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark has a tendency to tell them to have sex with themselves whenever they question one of his decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him in line, Vincent. We can't afford any miscommunication. I hate this margin. 912 sols worth of food. We get there on 868. And that's assuming nothing goes wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark finishes putting on his spacesuit. Snaps his helmet into place. Grabs his toolkit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark steps into the airlock. Closes the door behind him. he does, we begin ANGLING towards the carbon-thread canva lining the side of the airlock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the depressurization process begins, the canvas starts STRETCH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the sheet RIPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hab breaches. In one-tenth of a second, the tear trav the length of the airlock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full force of the Hab's atmosphere rushes through the breach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock (with Mark in it) is LAUNCHED LIKE A CANNONBA It flies forty meters through the air -- 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK SLO-MO SHOT as the crops inside the HAB are DESTROY in the depressurization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMP to regular speed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! The airlock hits the hillside -- Mark's body SLAMS into the wall -- his faceplate SHATTERS -- the airlock FL and TUMBLES down the hill. Mark is tossed around inside l a ragdoll in a washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock rolls another fifteen meters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panicked breaths. Ringing ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark struggles to stay conscious. His head bleeding. Jesu Christ. What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks through the window. Sees the collapsed Hab. The debris of ruined equipment scattering the field between t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psssssshhhhhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark wipes the blood from his brow, rolls to his knees. Struggles out of his suit. Checks his wounds. He's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psssssshhhhhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock is leaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's heart starts to pound. He searches frantically for the leak, checking every seam, every inch of fabric...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psssssshhhhhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark checks his arm computer. Oxygen flow steady. This wi keep him alive. For now. But he has to find that leak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think, Watney. How do you find an invisible leak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does an inventory. He has his toolkit. He has the patc kit from his suit. Think, Watney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the knife out of the toolkit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cuts his own hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hacks a chunk clean out of it. Holds the loose hair tight. Then he goes back to the arm computer. BOOSTS the oxygen flow. Now, all I need is a spark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yanks the WIRES from the power generator free. Strips the casing. Here goes nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the wires in the oxygen flow, rubs them together create a SPARK. WHOOSH. He lights the hair on fire, creating the key to his plan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds his breath. Watches the smoke wisp and curl towards the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading right through the microscopic TEAR in the fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark grins. I've got you. Goes back to the toolkit. Finds that old stalwart of every NASA space mission: Duct tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears a piece free. Seals the hole. The hissing stops. Mark breathes. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark cuts off one of the arms from his EVA suit. Cuts it into one square piece. Opens the patch kit. Works fast to glue the square over the area where the faceplate used to Then glues the arm-hole shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM! Mark slams his back into the airlock wall, hitting with enough force so that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock ROLLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clumsy -- like rolling a phone booth from inside -- it works. The airlock rolls a little less than a meter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes a breath. Girds himself to do it again... 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock has traveled the fifty meters so that it's no close to the Hab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark exits the airlock. He's wearing the patched-up suit. Which means his faceplate is completely covered with fabr and he only has one arm free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points the free arm in front of him and begins to walk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is using the camera in his arm computer to navigate. The camera projects an image onto the inside of the faceplate. Which is now fabric. It's crude, but it'll wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK'S POV: Mark hurries through the rip in the airlock. Stumbles through the deflated Hab, past the mess of debri heading for the bunk. Finds what he's looking for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez' SUIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands in the center of the Hab. We finally get a go look at it. And it's A MESS. Equipment overturned, debris everywhere. But the worst part?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's crops are RUINED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at the disaster of frozen soil and uprooted plants. All his work. His lifeline. Destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the mess for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he begins to clean it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at the keypad. Takes a moment to compose his words. God, how do I explain this? As he begins to type..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crops are dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent, Teddy, Annie and a team of others study the anal reports. Mood is somber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete loss of pressure boiled off most of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any bacteria that survived, died in the sub-zero temperatures when exposed to Mars' atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can still eat the potatoes he has, he just can't grow any more. We estimate they'll give him about 200 sols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And rations get him to what? Sol 409?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So with potatoes he can stretch to 609.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Sol 868 he'll be long dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have to launch as soon as possible. Which changes our travel time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're working on it. Prelim estimates call for a four-hundred fourteen day trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sol 135 now. We need thirteen days to mount the boosters and perform inspections. Which gives Bruce and his team...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-seven days to make this probe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it normally take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months. Minimum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna let you call Bruce and give him the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and his team sit around a speakerphone. They've jus hung up with Vincent. Everyone looks suitably SHELLSHOCKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is at a loss for words. You might as well have t this team they have to build a unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, uh... I'm gonna need a change of clothes. We're all gonna need a change of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hermes continues on its course back to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Mark..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez types at his terminal.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Apparently, NASA's letting us talk to you now, and I drew the short straw. Sorry we left you behind on Mars, but we don't like you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark reads his email.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Also, it's a lot roomier on the Hermes without you. We have to take turns doing your tasks, but it's only botany (not real science.) How's Mars?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark types his response.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Dear Martinez, Mars is fine. I accidentally blew up the Hab, but unfortunately all of Commander Lewis' disco music still survived."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez reads Mark's response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "How's the Hermes? Cramped and claustrophobic? Every day I go outside and look at the vast horizons just because I can."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tell the others I said hello."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez types. We see his response on his screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Will do."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to work. No choice. Mark clears the detritus from inside the Hab. Stares at the hole in the airlock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark covers the hole with Hab canvas. Begins strapping it place with duct tape. Doubles up the tape in a circular pattern. Studies his work. It's not pretty, but with a little luck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark repressurizes the Hab. Watches the canvas stretch as the pressure equalizes. He holds his breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canvas holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes inventory of his remaining potatoes. Outside, gusts of wind slam the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tries to stay focused on the matter at hand. Tries n to think about the fact that his life is currently held together by duct tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep working, Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sleeps in his office, half-on and half-off his smal love seat. He snores ever-so-slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his computer screen, we see orbital computations runni Vectors between Earth and Mars cycle over and over.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE WATKINS pokes his head in Rich's office. Rich stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich? Wake up. Sorry, they're asking for the probe courses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich nods. Grabs the old cup of coffee from his end table Takes a big drink. His face registers shock. He opens his mouth and lets the coffee fall directly on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know we're coming at this backwards, but we can't commit to a firm launch date with this many unknowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. All twenty-five models will take four-hundred fourteen days to reach Mars. They vary only slightly in thrust duration, and the fuel requirement is nearly identical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Rich's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-hundred fourteen days. Not an ideal time to launch, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth and Mars are really badly positioned. Heck, it's almost easier to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich trails off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost easier to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost in his head) I need more coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost easier to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand I'm your boss, right? 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent dictates a message to Mark. Mindy types while he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...the probe will take 414 days to reach you, and will deliver enough food to last you to Ares 4."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him about the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We've officially named the probe `Iris'..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark reads the message in the Rover.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "After the Greek goddess who traveled the heavens with the speed of wind. Among other things, she's also the goddess of rainbows."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark types his response...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mindy reads Mark's response on his screen as Vincent wait Mindy suppresses a smile, throws it up on the main screen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Gay probe coming to save me. Got it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy addresses the group from the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's ask the... (consults his files) Two hundred million dollar... sorry, five hundred... That's a "five?" (off their looks) Let's ask the very, very expensive question: is this probe gonna be ready on time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce looks noticeably more exhausted than everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen days. If I had another fifteen days, I could get it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's create fifteen days. Thirteen days to mount the probe. Can we reduce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It... actually only takes three days to mount it. We can get that down to two. But the other ten are for testing and inspections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often do those inspections reveal a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room goes silent. Everyone trades nervous glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting we don't do the inspections?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now I'm asking how often they reveal a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About one in twenty launches. But that's grounds for a countdown halt. We can't take that chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone else know a safer way to buy more time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Dr. Keller to stretch Watney's rations four more days. She won't like it, but that'll get us to fifteen. And we'll cancel the inspections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on me, Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got your two weeks. Get it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at the table. A ration pack and two potatoes in front of him. He talks to camera. He looks depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I have to hold out until the probe gets here with more food. And this is what "minimal calorie count" looks like. (holds up the pack) Standard issue ration. But instead of three every one day, I'm now eating one every three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good. Meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He divides the meatloaf into thirds. Sets the majority aside. Focuses on what's left. Which is pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is today's allotment. Which I will supplement with potatoes. Which I am beginning to hate with the fiery passion of a thousand suns. And now I've been told to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hacks off even more of the meager ration and half of potato and sets that aside. There's barely anything left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, "Stretch the rations four more days" is a real dick-punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are also two pills on the table. Mark crushes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dipping this potato in Vicodin and there's nothing anyone can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IRIS PROBE, now mounted on the booster, is readied fo launch. WATER VAPOR clouds the launchpad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final SUPPLIES are loaded into the probe. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full house. Mitch presides over the room, in his element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God, Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several. My mother's Catholic and my father's Hindu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take all the help we can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch puts on his headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Flight Director. Begin Launch Status Check.

dialogues.speaker: LAUNCH CONTROL, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Roger that, Houston...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Mitch runs through the status check...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy watches the countdown clock from the observation ro He looks over what appears to be a SPEECH. We catch a few words, including, "...successful launch..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy closes the speech in a BLUE FOLDER. As the clock approaches 00:00:15....

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (ON THE FLOOR)
dialogues.text: This is Flight. We are go for launch on schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE FLOOR: Vincent leans against the wall. Deep breath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE paces in front of the NINE TELEVISIONS in her offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE sits with his engineers, all in rapt attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICH PURNELL works on orbital calculations at his compute Isn't paying attention to the launch at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIFTOFF. Clamps RELEASE, the booster FIRES --

dialogues.speaker: TIMER CONTROLLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...and liftoff of the Iris Supply Probe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHEERS course through the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While team members congratulate one another, the LAUNCHER INTERFACE frowns at his station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting a little shimmy, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIOLENT SHIMMY rattles the payload as the craft ACCELERATES. The bolt at the forefront CRACKS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the first stage depletes its fuel, it JETTISONS the st clamps. As the stage begins to fall away from the shimmyi craft, it CATCHES HOLD, swinging unnaturally to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second stage engines IGNITE -- 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOSH -- the acceleration SHAKES the craft. The BOLT SHE CLEAN OFF -- the payload ROCKS -- THE OTHER FOUR BOLTS SN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris slips from its supports, and SLAMS INTO THE HULL --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALARMS and LIGHTS flash across the consoles. A cacophony urgent voices from the floor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Flight, we're getting a large precession!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Force on Iris at 7 G's. Intermittent signal loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Launch, what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's spinning on the long axis with a 17 degree precession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lost readings on the probe, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. It shook loose in the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loss of signal, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.O.S. here, too. Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voices go SILENT. The alarms BLARE. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SatCon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No satellite acquisition of signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch looks to the main screen. It GOES BLACK, with LARGE WHITE LETTERS reading: "L.O.S."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight, US Destroyer Stockton reports debris falling from sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREENS: cameras catch glimpses of debris trails falling from the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Mitch Henderson says the words every Flight Director hopes he never has to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GC, Flight. Lock the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent sits in his office. NASA is eerily silent now. It night. Vincent stares into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. He's been motionless so long, the sensors think th office is empty and shut off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent shifts. The lights click back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chime RINGS OUT on his computer. Vincent glances at the screen, sees a relayed message from Pathfinder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "WATNEY: How'd the launch go?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOMBER REDS of MARS blaze against the spacescape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands outside. The horizon reflects off his facepla

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, um. Commander Lewis. I need you to do something for me. If I die. I need you to check on my parents. They'll want to hear about our time on Mars first- hand. I'll need you to do that. It won't be easy talking to a couple about their dead son. It's a lot to ask; that's why I'm asking you. I'm not giving up. Just planning for every outcome. Please tell them I love what I do. And I'm really good at it. And I'm dying for something big and beautiful. And greater than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them I said I can live with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive headquarters in the heart of Beijing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: Teddy and Vincent answer questions from reporte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we substituted protein cubes for the standard rations. The thrust of the launch, combined with the simultaneous lateral vibration, liquefied the cubes and created an unbalanced load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't this accounted for in the inspection phase?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In order to make our launch window, we were forced to accelerate our schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You skipped the inspections?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a MAN'S VOICE. He speaks in SUBTITLED CHINESE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their astronaut is going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal A MAN AND A WOMAN watching the monitor. The voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: ZHU TAO, Under-Director, CNSA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. Perhaps not. (hands Guo the brief) The Taiyang Shen's booster. Our engineers have run the numbers, and it has enough fuel for a Mars injection orbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: GUO MING, Director, CNSA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (are you kidding?) Why hasn't NASA approached us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know. Our booster technology is classified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if we do nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world would never know we could have helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then. Merely for the sake of argument, let's say we decide to help them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be giving up a booster and effectively cancelling Taiyang Shen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUO considers this. But he's already made the decision...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to keep this among scientists. A cooperation between space agencies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're SLOWLY PUSHING IN on Teddy as he listens to the voi on the other end of the phone detail the terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy closes his eyes. Relief washes over him. It takes h a moment to realize they're waiting for his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce stands at the white boards, addressing his departme heads. He's energized, writing like a madman while he tal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, thanks to our friends in China, we get one more chance at this. We finished the Iris probe in sixty-three days. Now we get to do it again in twenty-eight... 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich Purnell stares at the calculations on the screen. Ca these be right? He runs the numbers again. As he sees the readout on his screen, he grins: holy shit, I'm right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich hurries through the halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're jettisoning any sort of landing system -- the idea is we're only sending rations, so they can crash land on Mars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich barges into to Vincent's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should hang up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Rich Purnell and I work in astrodynamics and you should hang up the phone right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich hands Vincent his summary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're FOLLOWING ANNIE as she hurries into the briefing ro Vincent, Rich, Bruce, and Mitch are already there. Annie' reading the email on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is "Project Elrond?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to make something up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Elrond?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's a secret meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that? Why does "Elrond" mean "secret meeting?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Council of Elrond. From Lord of the Rings. It's the meeting where they decide to destroy the One Ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I so quit right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're calling something Project Elrond, I would like my codename to be "Glorfindel."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god I hate every one of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy doesn't even know what this is about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them exactly what you told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get the Hermes back to Mars by Sol 561.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... what? Jesus. It's as though Rich just dropped a bomb in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich looks around. Grabs items off the table to demonstra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... let's pretend this stapler is the Hermes. And you are... I'm sorry, what's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the Director of NASA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Teddy, you're Earth. And right now the Hermes is heading towards you and is about to start its month-long deceleration to intercept. But, instead, I'm proposing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We start accelerating immediately, to preserve velocity and gain even more. We don't intercept Earth at all, but we come close enough to use a gravity assist to adjust course. While we're doing that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the pen out of Teddy's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We resupply with the probe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taiyeng Shen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick up whatever provisions we need... and then we're accelerating towards Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Mars. And we're going too fast at this point to fall into orbit, so it's a flyby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good is a flyby if we can't get Watney off the surface?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney would have to intercept using the MAV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent demonstrates, blasting his pen off of Annie's shoulder. Rich catches it, and points everything back towards Teddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we head back home. I've done the math. It checks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group sits in stunned silence. Teddy's the first one grasp the full magnitude of what they've just proposed. H locks eyes with Vincent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's no mistaking Teddy's tone, so Rich does exact that. After he leaves the room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we need to use the Taiyeng Shen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I missing? Why is that important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we can only do one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send Watney enough food to last until Ares 4, or send Hermes back to get him right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both plans require the Taiyang Shen, so we have to choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Hermes crew? We'd be asking them to add... (does the math) 533 days to their mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't hesitate. Not for a second. That's why Vincent called this meeting. He wants us to decide instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent nods. That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. It should be Commander Lewis' call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a matter of life and death, Mitch. We need to make this decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the Mission Commander. Life and death decisions are her damn job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the Hermes function for 533 days beyond the scheduled mission end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should. The Hermes was made to do all five Ares missions, so it's only halfway through lifespan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if something went wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would lose the crew. And the Ares Program with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what? We either have a high chance of killing one person, or a low chance of killing six people. How do we make that decision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't. Teddy does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on Teddy now. The room sits in silence. Teddy thinks for a long time. Feeling the full burden of leadership. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still have the chance to bring five astronauts home safe and sound. I'm not risking their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them make that decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch. We're going with option one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch stares at Teddy. Quietly seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goddamn coward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark trudges out of the airlock, goes about his routine. walks over to the solar panels, starts to scrub them for (what seems like) the thousandth time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do it anymore. He stares at them for a long time Then drops the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the top of the hill. Sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Mark hasn't moved. The sun is beginning to set. Th temperature ALARM on his suit is beginning to BLARE. It g cold FAST on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark overrides the alarm. Sits in the silence. As he glances back towards the setting sun, something METALLIC glints in the dust beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Mark gets up. Walks towards it. It's Vogel's specime drill. Dropped when the storm hit. Mark looks around, see the HOLES drilled in the rock formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fingers trace the unfinished work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SATELLITE VIEW: We can see Mark making his way to the Rov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been doing EVAs throughout the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent is hovering over Mindy's station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pattern to them. He goes out three hundred meters. Then stops. Three hundred more meters. Then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And nobody gave him instructions? Did JPL schedule something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mindy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at the Rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're receiving a transmission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls it up on the screen. Frowns. It's a jumble of numbers and data.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Chem analysis... sample batch 1A-7C..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent's the first to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Lewis' geo-compositing experiments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mindy frowns. I'm sorry, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent looks at the screens. Admiration in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's finishing the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark addresses camera while he works at the experiment ta diligently crushing the rock samples and testing them wit his chemistry set. Still somber. But he's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We evac'd eighteen sols into a thirty-one sol mission... Which means we've got thirteen sols of experiment and research schedules. For each of us. So. Commander Lewis... your work's in good hands. Beck -- I'll be honest with you, I don't understand chemolithotrophic detection. At all. But I'm doing my best. Johanssen, I know you don't like it when I touch the ChemCam, but guess what? I'm touching the ChemCam. Vogel, I think I've got a new cataloguing system for the core samples that I've titled "Das Core Samples" out of respect for the Fatherland. And Martinez... I still don't know what it is you do. Why did we bring you? No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to keep everything documented and organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's not exactly my strong suit, but I want it all to make sense, in case... you know. Maybe you can teach it in class someday. The Watney Syllabus. "How to Make a Bathtub Using NASA Tubing and an Old RTG." "How to Cook a Potato Six-Thousand Different Ways." "How to Make Water Out of Rocket Fuel. To Keep You Alive. For Just A Little Longer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his computer, Vogel runs a diagnostic check on the ship's engines. As he finishes his work for the day, he turns his attention to his Email. Frowns when he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Subject: Unsere Kinder"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our children? That's strange. He tries to open the attachment, but it's unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogel glides along passage to the Rec Room. Johannsen jog within the rotating drum. Vogel approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen leads Vogel into the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an email from my wife. The subject line says "Our Children," but the computer won't open the attachment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a look. (as she works) Huh. This isn't a jpg. It's a plain ASCII text file. Looks like... I don't know what this looks like. Math equations. Does this make any sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Rich Purnell Maneuver." Ja. It is a course maneuver for the Hermes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Vogel tries to make sense of what he's looking at, phrase in particular stands out on the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein Gott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All five crew members are seated around the main table in Rec -- the cramped area of the ship used for personal tim Lewis finishes briefing the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the mission would conclude with Earth intercept 211 days later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives the others a chance to absorb the news. They tr astonished glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would this really work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran the numbers. They check out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a brilliant course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why all the cloak and dagger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NASA rejected the idea. They'd rather take a big risk on Watney than a small risk on all of us. Whoever snuck it in Vogel's email obviously disagreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. We're talking about going directly against NASA's decision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. If we do the maneuver, they'll have to send the supply ship or we'll die. We have the opportunity to force their hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we gonna do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were up to me, we'd already be on our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it? Up to you, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this time. This is something NASA expressly rejected. We're talking about mutiny. Which is not a word I use lightly. We do this together, or not at all. Before you answer, consider the consequences. If we mess up the supply rendezvous, we die. If we mess up the Earth gravity assist, we die. If we do everything perfectly, we add 533 days to our mission. 533 more days before we see our families again. 533 days of unplanned space travel where anything could go wrong. Something might break that we can't fix. If it's mission critical, we die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, cowboy. You and I are military. There's a good chance we'd be court- martialed when we got home. As for the rest of you, I guarantee they'll never send you up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we go for it... how would it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plot the course and execute it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remote Override. They can take over the Hermes from Mission Control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you disable it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hermes has four redundant flight computers, each connected to three redundant comm systems. We can't shut down the comms; we'd lose telemetry and guidance. We can't shut down the computers; we need to control the ship. I'd have to disable the Remote Override on each system... It's part of the OS, I'd have to jump over the code...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen used to go by the hacker handle "Lady Sorrow" in high school. Just so we're all on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck is a liar. And he should keep our conversations private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, yeah. I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be unanimous. If anyone says no, that's it. We go home as planned. But I vote yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vote yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we do this, it would be over nine hundred days of space. That is enough space for one life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck thinks about it long and hard. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there was one. All eyes turn to Johanssen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johanssen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Johanssen glances up at us, feeling the full weight of world on her small shoulders --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRENDAN HATCH oversees Mission Control from 1 a.m. to 9 a The shift is much quieter than the day shift. Usually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight, CAPCOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go CAPCOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unscheduled status update from Hermes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. Read it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I don't get it, Flight. No real status. Just a single sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message reads: "Houston, be advised: Rich Purnell is a steely-eyed missile man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Who the hell is Rich Purnell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALARMS start ringing out on the various stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight, Guidance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go Guidance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hermes is off-course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPCOM, advise Hermes they're drifting. Guidance, get a correction ready --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative, Flight. It's not drift, they've adjusted course. Deliberate 27.812 rotation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell? CAPCOM, ask them what the hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Flight. Message sent. Minimum reply time 3 minutes, 4 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telemetry, any chance this is instrumentation failure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god. Guidance, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work out how long they can stay on this course before it's irreversible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working on that now, Flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And somebody find out who the hell Rich Purnell is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy's staring out the window when Mitch enters. Teddy makes him wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie will go before the media this morning and inform them of NASA's decision to reroute the Hermes to Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That seems like the smart move. Considering the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have killed the whole crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever gave them the maneuver only passed along information. The crew made the decision on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy looks at him. Don't give me that horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fighting the same war. Every time something goes wrong, the world forgets why we fly. I'm trying to keep us airborne. This is bigger than one person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy relents. Just slightly. God, I hope you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When this is over... I'll expect your resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat; then) I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (we're finished here) Bring our astronauts home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath us, sunlight creeps across the ridges of the Schiaparelli Crater. We PRELAP the sound of DRILLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Ares mission requires three years of presupplies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks directly to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so NASA figured out it's a lot easier to ship some of this stuff ahead of time rather than bring it with us. So, as a result, the MAV for Ares-4 is already waiting at the Schiaparelli Crater. And the plan is to use it to launch me into orbit just as the Hermes is passing. And then, I guess... they catch me? In space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark thinks about that. Grins. Okay, I guess that sounds awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, that's not really my problem right now. First, I have to get there. And it's 3,200 kilometers away. So I have 200 sols to figure out how to bring everything here that's keeping me alive -- the Atmospheric Regulator, the Oxygenator, and the Water Reclaimer -- along for the ride. Luckily, I have the brainpower of the entire planet Earth helping me with this endeavor. So far we've come up with, "Drill holes in the roof of your rover and then hit it with a rock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: The opening CHORDS of "Starman" by David Bowie us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, in his MAV SUIT, stands on top of Rover Two. He hol the large ROCK SAMPLE DRILL like a jackhammer, drilling h through the roof. It's grueling work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been at this a while: we catch a glimpse of the SEVE HUNDRED HOLES he's drilled around the edge of the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes the last hole. Then he grabs a SCREWDRIVER. A a ROCK. Jams the screwdriver between the holes like a chisel. WHACK! He hits it with the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHACK! He hits it again. And again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Didn't know what time it was the lights were low, oh, oh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark positions the partially-disassembled rover in front the camera. Frames his handiwork. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I leaned back on my radio, oh, oh..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and his engineers study Mark's photograph. Okay, good. The engineers start sketching out what to do next..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Didn't know what time it was the lights were low, oh, oh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleary Teddy and Mitch step into the lobby of the China National Space Administration. They find Zhu and Guo wait for them with an entourage. As they shake hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There's a starman waiting in the sky..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, inventories his remaining ration packs while he eat potato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He labels a few ration packs as he sets them aside: "Departure," "Birthday," "Last Meal..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hermes approaches Earth, slowing rotation... 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez talks to his wife, MARISSA, on a screen in the v booth. She's upset with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred and thirty-three days longer? And you said yes to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. He would have done the same for me. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think I'm gonna forgive you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, he's right. After a moment, she holds her han up to the screen. He does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and his team oversee the Iris 2 Probe as it's loade into shipping containers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few Chinese members of the CNSA (dressed in protective gear) watch as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, floating now due to the lack of centripetal gravit talks on the computer to her husband, ROBERT. It's clear they love each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it at the flea market. Original. Pressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert holds up a vintage 1973 copy Abba's Greatest Hits album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis squeals when she sees it. Claps with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Iris 2 Probe is attached to the booster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch engages in a heated argument with the Chinese Fligh Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All due respect to your CNSA protocol, we haven't done things that way since Apollo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The translator tries to translate his words. Zhu raises h eyebrows, glances at Teddy -- is this guy for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy shakes his head, Don't look at me, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark seals the tent to the roof of Rover 2, then pressuri it. Checking for leaks. It's like a hot-air balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and his engineers are doing the exact same thing they have a mirrored set of Mark's equipment. They try to figure out how to fit the Oxygenator into the pop tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogel entertains his WIFE and their young CHILDREN. He fl from a low-G area into a non-G area. ON THE SCREEN: The k laugh and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taiyang Shen LAUNCHES. Mitch, Teddy, and the Chinese scientists all clap, shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He told us not to blow it `Cause he knows it's all worthwhile..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, bops his head to the music as he drives Rover 2 acr the dunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Iris 2 probe separates from its booster rocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez takes control of the probe. He pilots it towards the Hermes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The probe approaches the Hermes as the docking procedure begins... 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck, geared up in his EVA suit, tethered to the wall, gu the probe to the docking port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johannsen watches anxiously through the window port as Be secures the docking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck, geared up in his EVA suit, tethered to the wall, gu the probe to the docking port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Let the children lose it, let the children use it, let a the children boogie..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hermes, rotating once again, soars through space on i return journey to Mars. It leaves the Earth behind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the music slowly FADES OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hold in silence on the Red Planet, the title takes little longer than usual to appear onscreen....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about laws on Mars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's OVER SIX MONTHS LATER, so a lot has changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an international treaty saying no country can lay claim to anything that's not on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Rovers are now hitched together. Pathfinder rides on top of Rover 1 like Granny Clampett. Rover 2 houses all t equipment. The whole thing looks like a Gypsy caravan mad of billion dollar NASA equipment.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: And by another treaty, if you're not in any country's territory, maritime law applies. So Mars is "international waters." 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hab is similarly transformed. All the major equipment has been stripped for parts. Sections of the canvas have cut down, re-glued, making the tent lopsided in places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NASA is an American non-military organization, and it owns the Hab. So, as soon as I step outside, I'm in international waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark talks directly to camera. The six months have transformed him as well. He's GAUNT. His hair is longer. His impressive beard shapes his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the cool part. I leave this morning for the Schiaparelli crater, where I will commandeer the Ares 4 lander. Nobody explicitly gave me permission to do this, and they can't until I'm aboard the Ares 4. So I will take control of a craft in international waters without permission. Which, by definition, makes me a pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark Watney, Space Pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than winning the Nobel Prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last day in the Hab. Mark shaves his beard. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark organizes the boxes and boxes of experiments he was keeping alive during his time in the Hab. Among the label we see "Das Soil Samples." CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pulls on his suit. Performs final shutdown. All the computers, lights, heaters go DARK. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark depressurizes the Hab. Stares at it for a moment. Thank you for keeping me alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens Rover 2. We catch a glimpse inside: it's fille with frozen potatoes and scavenged equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tosses the box of remaining rations inside. We catch glimpse of one of the labels: "Goodbye, Mars."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark climbs into Rover 1. Powers up the system. Here we g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark rolls out of the Hab site. Heading towards the horiz

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everywhere I go, I'm the first. It's a strange feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark leaves FOOTPRINTS in the red dirt as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Step outside the rover? First guy to be there. Climb that hill? First guy to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes careful note of one of the Martian moons (PHOB in the sky. Finds his course.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Four and a half billion years... nobody here. And now... me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the first person to be alone on an entire planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits outside the rover in his MAV suit while he wait for the solar panels to charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes in the view. Phobos arcs through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SATELLITE VIEW: Mark's caravan makes its way around the impressive Marth Crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mindy watches at her station. Vincent approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's our boy doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, so good. He's sticking to schedule. Drives for four hours before noon. Then sets the solar panels. And waits thirteen hours while they recharge. Sleeps somewhere in there. Then starts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's his morale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asked us to call him "Captain Blondebeard."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks about that... huh) Mars would be governed by maritime law, so technically --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he explained it to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROVER cuts across Mars. No music. Just quiet. Wheels turning in the rust-colored dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rover has a max speed of 25 kph, so it's slow going. hypnotic. Right now, it's the only thing moving on the entire planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE MARK. Watching the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stack of paperwork drops in front of Vincent. We notice diagrams for the MAV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we're gonna start by stating, for the record, that you're not gonna like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent starts to look through the plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is the intercept velocity. The Hermes cannot enter Mars orbit, or they'll never have enough fuel to make it home. The MAV is only designed to get to Low Mars Orbit. So in order for Mark to escape Mars' gravity entirely and intercept the Hermes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs to be going fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means we need to make the MAV lighter. A lot lighter. Five-thousand kilograms lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce gives him a look that says, well, that depends on y definition of "do that," Vincent. He begins to deconstruc scale model of the MAV:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were some gimmes right off the bat. The design presumes 500 kilograms of Martian soil and samples. Obviously, we won't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one passenger instead of six. With suits and gear, that saves another 500. Then we ditch the life support. We don't need it. We'll have Watney use his EVA suit for the whole trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will he use the controls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't. Martinez will pilot the MAV remotely from the Hermes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never had a manned ship controlled remotely before. (off Mitch's look) But... I'm excited for the opportunities that affords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we go remote, we can lose the control panels. Then we dump the secondary and tertiary comm systems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have a remote controlled ascent with no backup comms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not even to the bad stuff yet, Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better skip to the bad stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to remove the nose airlock, the windows, and Hull Panel 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (what?) You're taking the front of the ship off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The nose airlock alone is 400 kilograms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to launch a man into space with a giant hole in the front of the ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... no. We're gonna have him cover it with Hab canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hull's mostly there to keep the air in. Mars' atmosphere is so thin you don't need a lot of streamlining. By the time the ship's going fast enough for air resistance to matter, it'll be high enough that there's practically no air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sending him to space under a tarp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Can I go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really sure I want you to, but okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mindy reads Mark's response while the group awaits. Mitch looks on from his station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark says... "Are you f-word-ing kidding me?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he meant it like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Are you kidding me?" Or more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Are you kidding me?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't want to hurt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... possible he meant it the first way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at the camera with a look that says, "Oh jesu these JPL guys are gonna get me killed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what they're doing. I know what they're doing. They keep repeating "accelerate faster than any man in the history of space travel" like this is a good thing, like this'll distract me from how insane their plan is. Oh really? I get to be the fastest man in the history of space travel? You're launching me into space in a convertible. No no, it's worse, because I don't have any controls. You're launching me into space in a tin can. And, by the way, physicists don't even use words like "fast" when describing acceleration, so they're only doing it in hopes I won't raise any objections because I like the way "fastest man in the history of space travel" sounds. Well, you know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks about it) I do like it. I do like the way it sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. Let's do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: "Waterloo" by ABBA begins to play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands at the base of the MAV. He holds a large wren in his hand, almost like a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark stares up at the MAV with a gleam in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My my at Waterloo Napoleon did surrender..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tears the acceleration chairs out of the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHUMP. One after another, the acceleration chairs hit the dirt in a pile. WHUMP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tears out the control panels. He's having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHUMP. The controls hit the dirt. The pile is growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: "Waterloo" by ABBA begins to play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez runs through a flight simulation at his station. It's not going well. "Collision with Terrain" blinks in angry red letters on his screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... you killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis shrugs. The taskmaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez reboots the simulator... 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark waits in the airlock with a mess of stripped equipme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outside of the MAV now looks like the set of Sanford Son. Mark wrenches one of the MAV's hull panels free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP ABOVE: The nose airlock breaks free, and tumbles down towards camera, BLACKING OUT FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM BLACK, we FIND MARK. He's sitting on a hill slope, surveying his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAV has been TRANSFORMED. The whole front has been to off. Hab canvas now covers it. Equipment litters the area all around us. Junkyard on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Finally facing my Waterloo..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark just sits. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music FADES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hermes halts rotation as it approaches Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the plan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole crew is present for the state of the union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martinez will fly the MAV. Johanssen will sysop the ascent. Beck and Vogel, I want you in Airlock 2 with the outer door open before the MAV even launches. Once we reach intercept, it'll be Beck's job to get Watney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might be in bad shape. The stripped down MAV will get up to 12 g's during the launch. He could be knocked unconscious and may have internal bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then it's a good thing you're our doctor. What's the intercept plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finished attaching the tethers into one long line. It's 214 meters long. I'll have the MMU, so moving around should be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fast a relative velocity can you handle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I get to Mark? I can grab the MAV at 5 meters per second. 10 is like jumping onto a moving train. Any more than that and I might miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got some leeway. The launch will be 52 minutes before the intercept and it takes 12 minutes. As soon as Mark's engine cuts out we'll know our intercept point and velocity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. And 214 meters isn't a hard limit, per se.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take off the tether, I could get way out to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an option. Vogel, you're Beck's backup. All goes well, you're pulling them back aboard with the tether. If things go wrong, you're going out after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's go get our boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits inside the makeshift pressurized tent. He tears open his last remaining ration pack:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Goodbye, Mars"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mob scene at NASA. Networks from all across the gl have sent teams to cover the event. Campers, crews, and chaos all around as everyone fights for real estate in th biggest story of the century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New-Years-Eve-Level crowds gather in Times Square. On the Jumbotron, news reports announce the "Watney Rescue."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy, Vincent, and Annie watch from an observation area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If something goes wrong, what can Mission Control do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a damned thing. (off her look) It's all happening twelve light-minutes away. That means it takes twenty-four minutes for them to get the answer to any question they ask. The whole launch is twelve minutes long. They're on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that we have a choice, but... are we sure we want to be broadcasting this to the world? I mean, if something goes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to be broadcasting this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch takes his position as Johanssen's VOICE rings out:

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Fuel Pressure green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds watch the screens in Beijing as Johanssen's voice

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Engine alignment perfect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cold is not keeping the crowds from watching the scre in the Palace Square.

dialogues.speaker: JOHANSSEN, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Communications five by five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis nods. She's been waiting for this moment for some time. Keys the console --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About two minutes, Watney. How you doing down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tries to keep his emotions under control as he waits the cockpit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to hear your voice, Commander. I'm eager to get up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fails. His voice breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming back for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on the case. Remember, you'll be pulling some pretty heavy G's. It's okay to pass out. You're in Martinez' hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that asshole no barrel-rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy that, MAV. CAPCOM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON JOHANSSEN, at her station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remote Command...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON MARTINEZ, grinning in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recovery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON BECK as he floats in the open airlock. Beneath h the Red Planet blazes in all its brilliance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Secondary recovery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON VOGEL, clamped to the floor behind Beck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON MARK WATNEY, in his EVA suit, strapped into his acceleration seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL AROUND THE WORLD -- the CROWDS ERUPT IN CHEERS as the hear Mark's voice.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Mission control, this is Hermes actual. We are go for launch, and will proceed on schedule. 10 seconds to launch... mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Main engines start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8... 7... mooring clamps released...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five seconds, Watney. Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tenses in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in a few, Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is SLAMMED back into his acceleration couch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SFX: the MAV launches upward with incredible force. And y as discussed, in the history of space travel, no manned s has ever accelerated with more force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark can't even GASP -- the wind knocked out of him -- He struggles to remain conscious as the ship shakes VIOLENTL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK'S POV: staring forward, at the HAB CANVAS (which now patches where the nosecone used to be.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the ship accelerates, the canvas begins to RIP -- 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Velocity 741 meters per second. Altitude 1350 meters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too low --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's fighting me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Velocity 850, altitude 1843 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney? Watney, do you read? Can you report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mark's barely conscious -- his eyes drifting from terrified to serene as he fades --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIS POV -- the canvas RIPS FREE....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing the RED ATMOSPHERE of Mars. And as it thins -- we rocket towards the heavens -- the red gives way to the black...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the last thing Mark sees before he drops unconscious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the STARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's well below target altitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far below?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working on it -- Main shutdown in 3... 2... 1... Shutdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to automatic guidance. Confirm shutdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watney? Do you read?

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: He's probably passed out. He pulled 12 G's on the ascent. Give him a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have interval pings. Intercept velocity will be 11 meters per second...

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: I can make that work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distance at intercept will be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be 68 kilometers apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she say 68 kilometers? Kilometers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it together. Work the problem. Martinez, do we have any juice in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative, Commander. They ditched the OMS system to make launch weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we have to go him. Johanssen, time to intercept?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 minutes, 12 seconds --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we point our attitude thrusters all the same direction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on how much fuel we want to save for attitude adjustments on the trip home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could get by with maybe 20 percent of what's left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already working it) Use 75.5 percent of remaining attitude adjust fuel. That'll bring the intercept range to zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on -- that gets the range to zero, but the intercept velocity will be 42 meters per second --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we have 39 minutes to figure out how to slow down. Martinez, burn the jets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOSH. The attitude thrusters FIRE. The Hermes changes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON MARK as his eyelids flutter. He winces in pain a he slowly regains consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BENEATH HIM -- the orbiting MAV offers an unobstructed vi of Mars. The great red planet's horizon stretches out forever as the wispy atmosphere gives it a fuzzy edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's breathtaking. Awe-inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds up his middle finger. Fuck you, Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAV to Hermes --

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: Watney?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Commander.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: What's your status?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My chest hurts. I think I broke some ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: We're working on getting you. There was a complication during launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The canvas didn't hold...

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (OVER COMMS)
dialogues.text: I think it ripped early in the ascent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
